comments.commentBody: Maher is hardly on the side of truth and justice on many, many issues.  The man is an ardent advocate against vaccination and many of his health views are an anathema to science.

Richard Etal, don't look now, but...(gently, now)...you're *already* a mobile hotspot!

;)
Richard E. - My wife says she just wants to leave a smoking crater when she's gone.

RiA,

What does she smoke?

Sorry to be off-topic so soon, but I want to be a mobile hotspot when I retire.

http://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/13/technology/homeless-as-wi-fi-transmitt...

Now for the puzzle.
Where is the annual NYT interactive bracket?  Was it discontinued?  Why?

The only problem with your solution is you have to look at the mirror as well, i.e. Brazil being house -5 as well as house- 1.  Remember the houses could be on the left or the right hand of the street, so the furthest left house could be the first or the furthest right could be first.  Interesting that both ways lead to the same solution, though the order of the houses change.  On the left hand of the street ( Brazil = 1) the houses are yellow, blue, red, green and white, while on the right hand side it is green, white, red, blue, yellow.  I found it elegant that both worked.  But to answer your question I have not been able to solve with a different starting point or find a mathematically way of solving it.

There's a difference in that your job is a regular gig, and people know that tips are part of your compensation and they are expected to tip you (whether they do or not). You know from your own work experience and from those who held your job before you did approximately what you can expect to take in on a weekly or monthly basis, weigh that against your expenses, and decide whether the job matches your cost of living and meets your needs.

This was a one-time thing, for a few days, not a job. The assumption on the part of the agency folks was, "We can pay them whatever we want — they're homeless. Anything is better to a homeless person than nothing. And we'll let them 'keep' whatever they can hit people up for. That will be easy for them — they're used to begging, right?" And how exactly were the users of the mobile service supposed to know they were suppose to tip these folks. This is not a situation like waitering where there is an understood arrangement between the cusomter and the server. The homeless folks were expected to hit people up for donations, weren't they?

I mean, can anyone tell me what the customary gratuity is on a $0 tab for a roaming human hotspot? As a bartender, do you have to ask each bar patron to pay you extra money?

This is not directed at you, Robert, but the opinions about homeless people, who they are and what they deserve as human beings, as exhibited in the comments on this blog, are shocking and shameful.

These critics are nothing but sanctimonious hypocrites.  Apparently BHH's offense was forcing conference attendees to come face to face with the homeless and acknowledge their circumstances.  How awkward and uncomfortable!

I agree JeffW!  Jobs should go to creative artists and performers, not the poor "homeless" who are too stupid to realize they are being exploited!  Lets pass a law making it illegal to give a "homeless" a job!  Oh wait, we (effectively) already did that...
This is a funny experiment but definitely would prompt dispute over humanity. Maybe hot spot can be something else other than a human being?

Why is using the poor as basic slaves always a "clever" marketing idea? $20 a day plus whatever someone gives you is ILLEGAL for most of us, so why is it ok for the homeless? Because you think throwing them any scrap makes you look good? Because you think they are worth no more and should be "grateful"? Next thing, someone will suggest paying them $1 a day is "better than nothing," proving their disdain for these people. Without minimum wage, we go back to sweatshops and tentaments for all. Is this what those who worship the rich, for some ungody reason, want?

SBSW is bringing attention to the issue of homelessness, and giving homeless individuals cash to buy substantial meals. It may not be minimum wage, but it's something for people who would have nothing on any other day. Does anybody even have numbers for what they are making on goodwill "tips" in addition to their $20?
And all it cost was the dignity of 13 homeless people and $260 bucks a day. Brilliant!

I only agree about the 'you have never spent a day hungry' part. I work with homeless each week, serving them meals and hosting a shelter night at our church. Many ARE working, by the way; those that aren't would love a way to make some money. It is work; if you feel that you could go to a temp agency and hire people more like you to serve you (one commentator in the article), then why aren't you willing to help people whose plight might make you (and the rest of the tech world demographic - am in it, i know it) UNCOMFORTABLE.

It does seem that people's discomfort is with the fact that they are being forced to look at homeless people. Their outrage would be more convincing if they were actually doing something for the homeless.

This is just a cliche.

It is necessary that the banks and the individuals who perpetrated these crimes be punished and there not be any arbitrary limit on the extent of such punishment.

Institutions that benefit from the federal safety net should be held to a stricter standard of liability.

This settlement has the look, feel, and smell of another gift from the so-called regulators to their bank clients. The stated purpose of the deal was to allow the banks to get back to business. Some of the threats and promises made to bring AGs into line need to be scrutinized independently and the administration officials and the regulators need to be held accountable for their roles in the deal.

Yes they could have hired anyone they wanted, they don't need the homeless, but the homeless need money. So who are you really hurting when you cry "exploitation"? The line between "exploitation" and employment is completely subjective and relative. I suspect that there are probably 1 billion people on this planet who would love to get paid $20 plus tips to stand around in an air conditioned convention center.

By definition when your situation is so bad that no one will give you a "normal job", you're only option is either a handout or "exploitation" as you call it.
Peter, we're on the same page, but in answer to your first sentence, the t-shirt says, "I'm Clarence, a 4G hotspot."

The "workers" were "carrying mobile Wi-Fi devices," thus they themselves were not turned into anything. But why didn't the conference organizers and marketing agency pay them MINIMUM WAGE OR MORE? This is why we have laws, so workers are not taken advantage of given the power imbalances between employer and employees. That is where I see the exploitation. How about paying people an honest buck instead of encouraging them to beg (oh right, "ask for a donation") to make up the difference?
If I could recommend this ten times, I would. Krish, you have hit the nail on the head here. Pity the reporter was so naive.

Don't forget to look at it the other way around, the houses can be on the left or the right hand of the street.  So the first house is #5 or #1.  Then the order of the houses completely changes. Both come up with the same answer which is elegant, since I think it would be easy for the puzzle to only work on one side of the street. Yellow, blue, red, green, white on the left hand of the street versus green, white, red, blue , yellow on the right hand of the street.

Oh come on. They should have at least received the minimum wage! Would YOU want to stand there all day for a mere 20 bucks?

No matter how much it might 'seem' like $200, it still buys the same paltry amount at the grocery store.

My husband once got a job standing on Wall Street in a cow costume (to advertise new software)--he got $10.00/hour.

At least he was paid fairly for his time. That is what's at issue here.
and they got to be in a climate controlled room, in a new shirt with access to the facilities, they got to BELONG. i think the attendees didn't want to be reminded those folks exist.

Several years ago, Columnist Clarence Page of the Chicago Tribune wrote about an amusement park where Black men were the targets in the dunk tank. That didn't go over to well with the public or with him.

Anyway, all of the men were laid off. One of the newly unemployed men remarked to him that his column caused him to lose a decent paying job that provided the means for him to take care of his family.

For all of the people who were upset about these homeless men being exploited, what is the problem? When was the last time you helped a homeless person? Have you offered one of them a job? A meal? A place to stay? Or would you prefer the "out of sight, out of mind" routine?

$20 isn't a lot of money. However, if you're dead broke, unemployed, no prospects for the future, and all you have to forward to is going back to the homeless shelter, $20 can seem like $200 or $2000.

What's next? Are we going to pass a law that dictates the ways homeless people can make an honest living. And if they can't find work according to the law, it's for their own good because we know what is best for them while we sit in our nice house eating a good meal while our flat screen tv plays in the background.
If you really cared so much for the homeless, you would roll up your sleeves and go out in the field and work tirelessly with them day in and day out.

katieatl,
Because we choose as a society to turn our backs on them. Or are you going to say that these people choose to be homeless?

me neither, I thought first they do this even without money just for food.

Since 19th century red baron capitalism, we came a longway.

a decent 20 dollar payment.
I see very little wrong with hiring people to act as hotspots.
Though minimum wage would have been more thoughtful.

"Also, the argument of less is better than nothing is simply preposterous."

Can you explain how exactly this is preposterous? If I'm doing my math correctly here "Nothing" is less than "Less".....and what is it less than anyway?

There are only two ways to get a person to do something, Force and Money. As long as you are using Money instead of Force, the person has a choice. Do you have some evidence that the marketing company forced these homeless people? If not, then how is giving them a choice between 1) taking the job or 2) not taking the job WORSE than giving them no choice at all?

Do you feel the need to make homeless people's decisions for them? Sounds like you prefer Force over Money.
Just because of the fact that this issue is being discussed on the NYT , Mr. Gibbs should be give a promotion and a raise because of his business and marketing acumen -
